title: Al Aber
text:
Albert Julius Aber (July 31, 1927 – May 20, 1993) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a>. He appeared in 168 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> with the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> (, ), <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a> (1953–) and <a href="Kansas%20City%20Athletics">Kansas City Athletics</a> (1957). Born in <a href="Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, he threw and batted left-handed and was listed as tall and .
Aber graduated from West Technical High School and was signed as by the Indians at age 19 in 1946. He made his major league debut on September 15, 1950, pitching a complete-game victory, allowing two runs. He did not play another game in the big leagues until 1953, spending the 1951 and 1952 seasons performing military service during the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>. He appeared in six games for the Indians in 1953, winning one and losing one, before being traded on June 15 to the Tigers with <a href="Steve%20Gromek">Steve Gromek</a>, <a href="Ray%20Boone">Ray Boone</a> and <a href="Dick%20Weik">Dick Weik</a> for <a href="Art%20Houtteman">Art Houtteman</a>, <a href="Owen%20Friend">Owen Friend</a>, <a href="Bill%20Wight">Bill Wight</a>, and <a href="Joe%20Ginsberg">Joe Ginsberg</a>. Aber spent the next five years with the Tigers, where he compiled a 22–24 record. His best statistical season was 1955, in which Aber appeared in 39 games and won six, lost three, and had an <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> of 3.38. He was then waived by the Tigers, and was picked up by the Kansas City Athletics, for whom he pitched in three games, his final appearance coming on September 11, 1957.
In an interview in "<a href="SPORT%20%28US%20magazine%29">SPORT</a>" magazine in June 1956, Tigers catcher <a href="Frank%20House%20%28baseball%29">Frank House</a> noted that Aber threw a "heavy" ball: "I could catch Billy (<a href="Billy%20Hoeft">Hoeft</a>) with a fielder's glove. Although he's fast, he throws a 'light' ball that makes it easy on the catcher. Al Aber, another leftie on our staff, is tough to catch because he throws a 'heavy' ball."
Aber became a sales representative after retiring. He died in 1993 at age 65 in <a href="Garfield%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Garfield Heights, Ohio</a>.
